prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Specific factors articulated by the Panel—Size of actions

para.paratext: The Panel has considered the size of the various pending actions in determining whether it should order transfer of the cases for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[1] This factor is not likely to be an especially important factor, but it may affect the Panel's transfer decision in certain situations.

In one case the Panel considered the fact that numerous complex but very small cases were pending in various districts, and determined that transfer was appropriate in order to permit the orderly handling of the cases.[2] In fact, the considerations applicable in this situation are similar to those governing class actions.[3]

Although not directly a matter of size, the Panel may also look to the complexity of the cases. Obviously, perfunctorily simple cases, such as actions to quash subpoenas, are unlikely to benefit from centralization.[4] The Panel's approach to a series of cases involving claims relating to labels or packaging of food products provides a good window into how complexity may be considered. In one docket the Panel ordered centralization of six actions pending in three districts,[5] distinguishing mere “labeling” cases, which it had not historically centralized,[6] from cases alleging false “natural” claims, where centralization had been ordered.[7]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
In re Grain Shipments, 300 F. Supp. 1402, 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
In re Grain Shipments, 300 F. Supp. 1402, 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1969).

See, e.g., In re: Cybil Fisher Litigation, 987 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013); In re: James D. Jordan IRS Summons Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011); In re: Crystal Poole IRS Summons Litigation, 763 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011); In re: Good Karma, LLC, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2007) (“summary” actions to quash IRS subpoenas).
In re Coca-Cola Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation (No. II), 37 F. Supp. 3d 1386 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014).

See In re: Kashi Company Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 959 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013); In re: Skinnygirl Margarita Beverage Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 829 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011); In re: Nutella Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011).
See In re: Frito-Lay North America, Inc. All Natural Litigation, 908 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012).
